Despite recent reforms in the nonbank financial (NBF) sector, remains 
small, underdeveloped, and fragmented. It is highly segmented due to 
legal, regulatory, and institutional constraints, and investment products 
of  a  similar  nature  are  subject  to  different  regulations  and  taxation 
depending on whether they are offered by investment companies, pre-
need companies, insurance companies, or bank trust departments.   
 
High  taxes  on  secondary  market  transactions  in  debt  and  equity 
securities  have  particularly  impeded  the  development  of  efficient 
secondary  markets,  while  taxing  initial  public  offerings  (IPOs)  of  listed 
stocks and closed-end investment funds has made capital mobilization 
through  the  stock  exchange  less  attractive  to  corporate  issuers  and 
investors.  In  this  environment,  the  domestic  financial  market  has  not 
been  an  effective  mechanism  for  savings  mobilization.  The  result  is 
overreliance  on  external  borrowings  to  meet  both  public  and  private 
sectors’ financing requirements.  
 
In  the  current  economic  environment,  one  of  the  more  difficult 
challenges facing the Philippines is to create a foundation for the NBF 
sector  to  enable  it  to  provide  essential  financial  services  needed  to 
mobilize  the  supply  of  funds  for  business  investment.  To  meet  this 
challenge,  it  will  require  comprehensive  legal,  regulatory,  and  policy 
reforms  to  develop  a  more  efficient  and  competitive  NBF  sector; 
reduced  market  and  product  segmentation;  improved  governance  and 
risk management practices; and greater uniformity in the regulatory and 
prudential  standards  applicable  to  the  NBF  sector  and  investment 
products.  These  reforms  will  take  time  to  adopt  and  have  to  be 
implemented in sequences to ensure effectiveness.  
 
The  first  Nonbank  Financial  Governance  (NBFG)  program1  addressed 
(i) governance of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC); (ii) 
modernizing the governance and regulatory structure of the Philippines 
Stock  Exchange 
(iii)  strengthening  market  oversight, 
compliance, and enforcement of SEC; and (iv) facilitating diversification 
and innovation in corporate financing. Building on reforms under NBFG, 
four  areas  of  weaknesses  need  to  be  further  addressed  urgently  to 
pave the way for the recovery of the NBF sector. These areas include  
(i) weak and fragmented regulatory structure and policy; (ii) supervisory 
and surveillance capacities of SEC, the regulatory agency; (iii) financial 
information and disclosure and prudential standards for NBFIs; and (iv) 
overreliance on banks to mobilize savings.

The  Program  was  formulated  based  on  Objectives  and  Principles  of 
Securities  Regulation  of  the  International  Organization  of  Securities 
Commission  (IOSCO),  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  ongoing 
assistance in the sector, and the Mission’s findings. The goal of SNFG 
is  to  promote  the  development  of  the  nonbank  financial  sector  by  (i) 
strengthening the regulatory and policy framework for developing viable 
institutions and properly functioning financial markets; (ii) continuing to 
strengthen  SEC’s  enforcement  capacities,  supervisory  skills,  and 
practices;  (iii)  improving  transparency  to  protect  investors  from  fraud, 
insolvency,  or  misconduct;  and  (iv)  facilitating  the  mobilization  of 
domestic savings to increase supplies of funds while ensuring investor 
protection. 
 
To achieve these objectives, SNFG will seek to (i) establish an effective 
anti-money  laundering  regime;  (ii)  strengthen  investor  protection  and 
confidence  in  PSE;  (iii)  remove  policy  distortions  and  address  the 
fragmented  regulatory  framework  to  promote  market  efficiency  and 
development;  (iv)  clearly  define  SEC  supervisory  responsibilities  and 
enhance  its  monitoring  and  surveillance  capacity;  (v)  improve  the 
quality  of  financial  information  disclosed  to  the  market;  (vi)  strengthen 
prudential  standards;  and  (vii)  promote  the  development  of  collective 
investment  vehicles  and  establish  a  proper  framework  for  investor 
protection.  As  designed,  the  Program  will  move  the  Philippines  to  full 
compliance  with  all  of  IOSCO’s  30  Objectives  and  Principles  of 
Securities Regulation.

It  is  proposed  that  ADB  support  the  Government’s  policy  reforms  by

the  loan.  ADB  will  be  entitled  to  withdraw  the  front-end  fee  from  the 
loan account and pay itself on behalf of the Government. The loan will 
have an amortization period of 15 years, including a grace period of 3 
years.  The  loan  proceeds  are  expected  to  be  utilized  over  a  period  of 
36 months from the date of loan effectiveness. 
 
The  program  period  will  be  3  years.  The  loan  will  be  released  in  two 
equal  tranches.  The  first  tranche  ($75  million)  will  be  released  upon 
loan  effectiveness,  and  the  second,  18  months  after  Board  approval, 
subject  to  the  Government’s  meeting  the  conditions  specified  for  its 
release.  The  conditions  for  release  of  the  first  tranche  are  37  policy 
actions all of which have already been fully complied with. The second 
tranche ($75 million) will be released upon satisfactory compliance with 
13 policy conditions.

The Department of Finance (DOF) will be the Executing Agency for the 
SNFG  program  loan  and  SEC  will  be  the  Implementing  Agency.  SEC 
will  set  up  an  interagency  coordination  committee  headed  by  the 
chairperson  of  SEC  and  comprising  representatives  from  Anti-Money 
Laundering  Council,  Bangko  Sentral  ng  Pilipinas,  DOF,  Insurance 
Commission, National Economic and Development Authority, and PSE. 
The  committee  will  meet  every  quarter  to  coordinate  and  ensure 
effective  implementation  of  the  proposed  reforms.  ADB  will  also  be  a 
member of the committee to oversee the progress of the Program. 
 
The loan proceeds will be used to finance the foreign exchange costs of 
items  produced  and  procured  in  ADB  member  countries  (other  than 
items  specified  in  the  negative  list  of  ineligible  items  and  imports 
financed  by  other  bilateral  and  multilateral  sources).  The  Government 
will  certify  that  the  volume  of  eligible  imports  exceeds  the  amount  of 
ADB’s  projected  disbursements  under  the  loan  for  the  given  period. 
ADB reserves the right to audit the use of the loan proceeds and verify 
the accuracy of the Government’s certification. 
 
The  Government  will  use  the  local  currency  funds  generated  by  the 
SNFG  loan  to  meet  program  expenditures  and  associated  costs  of 
reform and to help maintain current levels of social expenditures. 
 
One of the principal risks associated with the Program is the resistance 
of  vested  interests,  particularly  as  the  Program  is  politically  sensitive 
and  seeks  to  end  money-laundering  activities.  To  minimize  the  risks, 
the policy actions have been formulated to cover reforms that are within 
the  executive  branch  of  the  Government  to  implement.  The  more 
difficult  reforms  requiring 
the  enactment  of  politically  sensitive 
legislation, including the passage of the amendments to the Anti-Money 
Laundering Act is included in the Program as a first tranche condition to 
prevent  the  possible  delayed  enactment  of  both  legislation  from 
affecting  the  implementation  of  other  significant  reforms  supported 
under  the  Program.    The  Government  has  shown  political  will  to 
implement 
the 
amendments to the Anti-money laundering law satisfactory to Financial 
Action  Task  Anti-Money  Laundering  were  passed  by  Congress  in 
March 2003. 
 
Apart from politically sensitive legislation, the Program will also impose 
significant  costs  to  the  private  sector,  particularly  as  firms  will  be 
required to adopt International Accounting Standards (IAS). While large 
accounting firms are likely to be able to more easily adopt the required 
changes, smaller firms will have greater difficulty and less resource for 
staff  retraining.  Likewise,  there  will  also  be  costs  to  all  companies 
registered with SEC as they will be required to change from Philippines 
General  Accounting  and  Auditing  Principles  to  IAS  as  their  staff  will 
have  to  be  retrained  to  meet  the  new  reporting  requirements.  The 
Program  recognizes  the  difficulty  and  costs,  associated  with  the 
changes and has made provision for the Government to adopt the new 
accounting  standards  gradually  until  2005.  While  the  transition  is 
relatively shorter than that in the European Union, the risks are deemed 
adequately  mitigated  as  the  Philippines  has  a  large  pool  of  well-
qualified  accountants,  making  the  transition  easier  than  in  many 
emerging markets.

 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Republic  of  the  Philippines  for  the  Second  Nonbank  Financial  Governance  (SNFG) 
Program.  The  report  also  describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Support  for  the 
Nonbank  Financial  Sector,  and  if  the  Board  approves  the  proposed  loan,  I,  acting  under  the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT1 

2. 
Driven  by  a  rebound  in  external  demand  and  strong  domestic  private  consumption 
(supported by a steady inflow of remittances), the Philippine economy outperformed most of its 
neighbors  in  2002  with  the  Gross  Domestic  Product  (GDP)  growing  by  4.6%  year-on-year.2 
Inflation last year was 3.1%, which was well below the Government’s target of 4.5-5.5% due in 
part  to  the  effects  of  a  less  accommodating  monetary  policy  stance  and  milder-than-expected 
weather-related disruptions to agriculture and transport, and low food prices. Nevertheless, the 
low rate of inflation reflected continued excess industrial capacity in some sectors and high (and 
rising) unemployment. However, as the world economic recovery remains uncertain, particularly 
in  the  Philippines’  export  markets  of  the  United  States  (US)  and  Europe,  the  outlook  of  the 
Philippine  economy  is  less  robust  over  the  short  to  medium  term.  Under  the  circumstances, 
GDP  in  2003  is  expected  to  grow  more  moderately,  probably  at  a  rate  4.0-4.5%.  Despite  a 
sharp rise in food prices in June, inflation should remain subdued in 2003 reflecting a negative 
output gap.  
 
The  shortfalls  in  the  revenue  collection  system  weaken  the  Government’s  fiscal 
3. 
performance  in  2002  and  caused  the  budget  deficit  to  widen  to  an  estimated  5.3%  of  GDP 
against  the  original  target  of  P130  billion  or  3.3%  of  GDP.  While  difficulties  with  revenue 
collection are not a new problem in the Philippines, the recent and highly criticized public focus 
on  this  issue  has  strengthened  the  Government's  resolve  to  undertake  reforms  in  this  area. 
Continued  difficulties  with  fiscal  management  in  the  short  run,  however,  are  likely  to  exert 
upward  pressure  on  interest  rates—dampening  domestic  demand  and  macroeconomic 
stabilization efforts. 
 
4. 
Despite the economy’s positive performance, growth has not been high enough to create 
more jobs for the rapidly growing labor force and unemployment continues to be high and rising.  
Higher levels of investment are necessary if the economy is to attain a higher growth path and 
unemployment is to be reduced.   
 
5. 
The  financial  sector  clearly  has  a  central  part  to  play  in  this  effort  through  its  role  of 
channeling savings to productive investment to finance growth. Currently, however, the financial 
sector in the Philippines is bank-dominated and lending by the banking system to the corporate 
sector  has  been  highly  constrained  by  banks’  nonperforming  loans  (NPLs)  that  have  steadily 
accumulated  since  the  crisis.  Latest  estimates  point  to  NPLs  at  above  15%  of  commercial 
banks’ total  assets. The  high  level  of  NPLs  within  the  banking  system  and  overreliance  of  the 
corporate sector on bank lending are symptomatic of weak governance in the financial sector, 
and  lack  of  alternative  sources  of  financing  to  the  banking  system.  Reforms  to  address  these 
distortions  and  support  the  development  of  a  sound  nonbank  financial  (NBF)  sector  are

A. 

Sector Description and Performance 

Regulation and Supervisory Framework 

1. 
 
The  NBF  sector  comprises  the  Philippine  Stock  Exchange  (PSE)3  and  a  variety  of 
7. 
financial  intermediaries  including  investment  houses, finance  companies,  broker-dealers firms, 
mutual  funds,  investment  management  companies,  insurance  companies,  and  pre-need  plan 
companies. Pawnshops and lending investors providing loans to individuals, money changers, 
and  money  transmitters  are  also  classified  as  nonbank  financial  institutions  (NBFIs)  in  the 
Philippines (Appendix 1). 
 
8. 
The  Securities  and  Exchange  Commission  (SEC)  is  the  main  regulator  of  NBFIs 
engaged in capital market activities. Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), the central bank, also 
regulates  and  supervises  NBFIs  that  are  subsidiaries  of  commercial  banks  and  those  with 
quasi-banking license, trust operations and foreign products and services, and pawnshops. SEC 
was  established  in  1936  under  Commonwealth  Act  83.  In  1975,  SEC  was  reorganized  under 
Presidential Decree 902A into a quasi-judicial body with authority to investigate and prosecute 
fraud  and  other  forms  of  misconduct,  adjudicate  corporate  disputes,  and  interpret  the  laws 
administered  by  SEC.  Under  Decree  902A,  SEC  was  also  responsible  for  supervising  the 
administration  of  insolvent  companies.  In  1982,  under  the  Revised  Securities  Act,  SEC  was 
given  authority  to  act  as  a  securities  regulatory  body.  In  addition  to  acting  as  a  securities 
regulatory body, SEC also serves as a registrar of companies, both publicly and privately held. 
 
9. 
The Government promulgated the Securities Regulation Code (SRC) in 2000. The SRC 
superseded  the  Revised  Securities  Act  and  Presidential  Degree  902A  and  has  narrowed  the 
mandate of SEC to regulation of the securities markets and enforcement. The new law allowed 
SEC  to  transfer  its  quasi-judicial  function  to  courts.  In  addition,  it  provides  SEC  with  greater 
autonomy, indemnification for its staff against lawsuits, and greater financial resources to meet 
SEC’s  new  mandate.  As  a  result  of  the  powers  granted  to  SEC,  no  domestic  or  foreign 
securities  other  than  exempt  securities  may  be  offered  to  the  public  without  being  registered 
with SEC. Under the new law, SEC is allowed, however, to continue to maintain its function as a 
registrar of both public and private companies. SEC, as such, supervises, not only companies 
with  publicly  traded  securities,  but  also  all  corporations,  partnerships,  and  associations,  which 
are required to register with SEC.  
 
10. 
The SRC requires the demutualization of PSE in response to the inside trading scandal 
in  2000.  Additional  laws  governing  NBFIs  include  the  Corporation  Code,  the  Investment

In  the  current  economic  environment,  one  of  the  more  difficult  challenges  facing  the 
Philippines is to create a foundation for the NBF sector to enable it to provide essential financial 
services  needed  to  mobilize  the  supply  of  funds  for  business  investment.  To  meet  this 
challenge, comprehensive legal, regulatory, and policy reforms are required for a more efficient 
and competitive NBF sector, reduced market and product segmentation, improved governance 
and  risk  management  practices,  and  greater  uniformity  in  the  regulatory  and  prudential 
standards applied to the NBF sector and investment products. These reforms will take time to

Building  on  reforms  under  the  nonbank  financial  governance  program  (NBFG),  four  areas  of 
weaknesses will be addressed to pave the way for the recovery of the NBF sector: (i) weak and 
fragmented  regulatory  structure  and  policy;  (ii)  supervisory  and  surveillance  capacities  of  the 
regulatory  agency,  SEC;  (iii)  financial  information  and  disclosure  and  prudential  standards  for 
NBFIs; and (iv) continued overreliance on banks to mobilize savings.

c. 

Unfavorable Policy Environment 

 
Taxes  are  identified  as  one  of  the  major  factors  impeding  market  efficiency  and 
27. 
development  of  the  NBF  sector.  There  is  no  capital  gains  tax  on  listed  equity  securities; 
however,  there  is  a  10%  value-added  tax  on  the  brokerage  commission.  Moreover,  all  shares 
and  stock  certificates  are  subject  to  a  stamp  duty  tax  of  1.0%  and  all  debt  instruments  to  a 
range  of  0.3-1.5%  documentary  stamp  tax  (DST),  depending  on  the  type  of  instrument  (i.e., 
debentures or CPs). For deposits in commercial banks, however, the DST is not applied across 
the  board.  Only  time  deposits  (with  a  minimum  of  P50,000)  are  subject  to  the  DST;  other 
deposits such as those in special accounts (with a minimum of P300,000) are DST exempt.    
 
28.  More  importantly,  when  traded,  both  debt  and  equity  instruments  are  subject  to  an 
additional  DST  on  the  buyer  and  a  stock  transaction  tax  on  the  seller,  which,  combined,  add 
1.25% to the transaction cost.  Failure to attach the stamp will make the document unacceptable 
in  third  party  transactions  and  cannot  be  used  as  evidence  in  court.  A  major  drawback  of  the 
DST  is  the  application  of  the  tax  every  time  the  instrument  changes  hand;  the  more  time  the 
financial instruments are traded, the higher the costs to the investors. The cascading feature of 
the DST discourages the trading of financial instruments and market development and, as such, 
reduces liquidity in the secondary markets, not only for debts but also for equity instruments.9 
 
29. 
The  tax  revenue  from  the  secondary  trading  of  equity  instruments  varies  with  the 
performance  of  the  equity  market,  ranging  from  about  P400  million  to  about  P1.4  billion 
annually, while that from secondary trading of debt instruments is estimated to range from P200 
million  to  P500  million.  The  tax  revenue  collected  from  DST  on  debt  and  equity  instruments 
represent less than 1% of the aggregate revenue. However, as DST is a relatively more reliable 
source of revenue and convenient to collect, it is very difficult for the Government to eliminate it.  
  
30. 
 Aside  from  the  DST,  equity  securities  listed  on  PSE,  including  closed-end  funds,  are 
subject to an initial public offering (IPO) tax of 2-4% depending on the float available to public 
shareholders. The IPO tax makes it more costly than it should be for business to raise needed 
capital for investment and reduces the Philippines’ ability to compete for issuers particularly in 
light of growing competition among the stock exchanges within the region. 
 
31. 
It is recognized that the NBF sector, like any other sector in the economy, should pay its 
share of tax revenue; however, taxation should minimize the distortions in the financial markets. 
The  above  taxes,  combined,  have  reduced  the  efficiency  of  financial  markets  and  have  made 
alternative sources to bank financing too costly.

2. 

SEC Supervisory and Surveillance Capacities  

33. 
As indicated earlier, the SRC has made SEC a more enforcement-oriented, operationally 
independent regulator with clear objectives and procedure. However, SEC needs to continue to 
work  on  enhancing  the  enforcement  skills  of  its  staff  to  ensure  effective  regulation  and 
enforcement.  Moreover,  its  electronic  information  management  capacity  needs  to  be  further 
enhanced  to  have  updated  information  readily  available  for  inspection,  investigation,  and 
surveillance. 
 
34.  While  regulatory  and  supervisory  authority  over  NBFIs  should  be  clearly  defined,  joint 
inspection  should  also  be  encouraged  where  necessary.  In the  Philippines,  three Government 
organizations  are  responsible  for  regulating  and  supervising  NBFIs;  (i)  SEC,  (ii)  BSP,  and  (iii) 
IC.  In  1999,  BSP  and  SEC  entered  into  an  agreement  on  the  exercise  of  regulatory  and 
supervisory authority over NBFIs (with the exception of insurance companies, which traditionally 
have  come  exclusively  under  the  domain  of  IC).  Under  the  agreement  BSP  is  responsible  for 
supervising  investment  houses  and  other  subsidiaries  and  affiliates  of  universal  banks,  which 
are also registered with SEC to perform capital market activities such as underwriting. As BSP 
is  moving  toward  consolidated  supervision,  which  will  result  in  a  reorganization  and  merger  of 
the  bank  and  nonbank  supervision  departments,  in  conjunction  with  building  an  effective 
consolidated  supervisory  framework,  it  would  be  highly  desirable  to  amend  the  agreement 
between BSP and SEC to provide for joint inspection by BSP and SEC. Joint inspection of the 
investment house and securities broker and dealer subsidiaries or affiliates of banks is essential 
to avoid potential gaps arising from separate on-site inspections and to allow the use of SEC’s 
expertise. 
 

3. 

Move to Strengthen Transparency and Prudential Regulations 

35. 
To  improve  the  quality  of  financial  information  and  disclosure,  the  Government  has 
gradually moved away from the Philippines General Accounting and Auditing Principles (GAAP) 
and  has  phased  in  the  adoption  of  auditing  and  accounting  standards  based  on  international 
auditing and accounting standards since 2001, with a target of completing adoption by 2004 and 
2005,  respectively.  Nevertheless,  other  standards  to  ensure  investor  protection  from  fraud, 
insolvency, or misconduct, including prudential, fit and proper standards, and a basic element of 
self-regulation should be established and/or further strengthened.   
 
36. 
First,  securities  broker-dealers  and  investment  houses  are  subject  to  inconsistent  capital 
requirements. Brokers and dealers in securities are subject to SEC’s net capital rule. The rule is 
largely risk-based and derived from the US SEC uniform net capital rule. Investment houses, on 
the  other  hand,  are  subject  to  capital  standards  defined  under  the  implementing  guidelines  of 

  10

BSP.10 More importantly, capital requirements for all types of NBFIs are not sufficiently calibrated to 
the  risks  they  are  assuming,  nor  do  they  provide  sufficient  early  warning  in  the  event  an  NBFI 
encounters financial distress that might lead to insolvency. As such, the capital standards should 
be revised and harmonized according to risks. In particular, NBFIs’ risks in securities and similar 
instruments  held  in  inventory  have  to  be  well  calibrated  and  harmonized  with  respect  to  both 
market  and  credit  risks.  There  should  also  be  a  tiering  of  initial  capital  requirements  (i.e.,  entry 
requirements) depending on the nature of the risks undertaken and the types of licenses obtained 
(i.e.,  broker,  dealer,  underwriter,  and/or  full  service  securities  market  intermediary  or  investment 
house). Lastly, ongoing risk-based capital standards should be in harmony with those advocated 
by 
International  Organization  of  Securities  Commission  (IOSCO)  for  securities  market 
intermediaries.    
 
Second, fit and proper standards are specifically defined in the Banking Act of 2000 but are 
37. 
not  included  in  the  SRC  or  the  Insurance  Law.  While  these  standards—which  allow  SEC  to 
prescribe, pass upon, and review the qualifications and disqualifications of appointed individuals 
or  elected  directors  and officers  and  to  disqualify  those found  unfit  to  serve—are  essential for 
regulating NBFIs and conform to international best practice, SEC and IC currently do not have 
sufficient authority to adopt them. Third, all members of PSE are required to have a designated 
compliance  officer  but  nonmembers  who  are  also  registered  with  SEC  to  engage  in 
underwriting,  government  securities  business,  or  investment  advisor  activities  do  not  have  a 
similar requirement. Compliance is the most important element of regulation or self-regulation, 
as  it  begins  at  the  individual  firm  level.  It  is  the  first  line  of  defense  in  an  effective  regulatory 
scheme.  It  would  be  highly  desirable  for  NBFIs  to  designate  a  compliance  officer  who  is 
required  to  serve  in  an  advisory  capacity  with  responsibility  to  develop  the  procedures  and

13. 
The  pre-need  industry  in  the  Philippines,  which provides benefits relating to education, 
pension funds accumulation, interment and death-related services, has grown remarkably since 
its  inception  in  1966.  The  industry  has  now  become  one  of  the  most  significant  savings 
mobilizers in the Philippines. Since 1977, nearly 161 million plans have been sold. From 1990 to 
2001,  pre-need  annual  sales  grew  at  an  average  rate  of  25%.  Throughout  the  past  decade, 
pension  and  education  plans  have  been  the  largest  selling  products  of  the  industry  and  have 
been  the  factor  sustaining  the  overall  growth  of  pre-need  product  sales.  In  absolute  terms, 
sales  of  life  and  memorial  plans  have  remained  unchanged;  however,  in  relative  terms,  they 
have been shrinking in size. Given its remarkable growth, the pre-need industry’s assets in the 
Philippines  totaled  P159.8  billion  in  2001,  compared  with  the  P147.5  billion  assets  of  the 
insurance  industry,  P82  billion  of  the  common  trust  fund,  and  P11.5  billion  of  mutual  fund  net 
assets.  In  2002,  however,  sales  of  the  pre-need  companies  dropped  by  2.3%  partly  as  the 
industry’s poor performance weakened plan holder confidence. 
 
The pre-need industry—by sales value or size of assets—is highly concentrated. From 
14. 
1991 to 2001, over 60% and 80% of the total industry’s sales were made by the top 5 and top 
10  pre-need  companies  (by  asset  size),  respectively.  For  industry-wide  profitability,  sales

Pre-Need  Plans.  Pre-need  plans  are  contracts that specify commitment of the pre-need 
companies  to  provide  specified  benefits  to  the  plan  holder  or  the  plan  holder’s  beneficiary  on  a 
scheduled date agreed upon at inception. In return, the plan holder is required to pay the pre-need 
company in cash or on installment as specified in the contract. Three types of pre-need plans are 
offered  to  plan  holders:  education,  pensions,  and  life  or  memorial  plans.  As  education  plans 
provide  plan  holder  beneficiaries  with  a  given  stream  of  income,  spread  along  a  certain  time 
period,  to  meet  educational  costs;  and  pension  plans  provide  predictable  income  flow  on 
beneficiaries’  retirement,  they  are  also  referred  to  as  scheduled  benefit  plans.  Life  or  memorial 
plans,  on  the  other  hand,  are  referred  to  as  a  contingent  benefit  plan  as  the  timing  of  benefits 
depends on the occurrence of a contingency.

The financial sector plays a powerful, through indirect role in reducing poverty by facilitating long-term economic 
growth.  Growth, however, is turbulent and not necessarily pro-poor.  Growth entails change, which the poor may 
often not be well-equipped to cope with.  A well-governed financial sector that facilitates competition can help make 
growth user-friendlier (i) improving access to savings, credit, and insurance instruments, which enable the poor to 
cushion shocks as well as take advantage of opportunities created by change; and (ii) allowing for better terms on 
those instruments.

A well-governed financial sector also reduces the likelihood and severity of financial and economic crises and 
consequently helps safeguard against a corresponding marked increase in the incidence of poverty.  Balanced 
financial sector development can promote financial system stability and strengthening by allowing risks to be more 
evenly spread among types of financial institutions and spurring competition between them.  The financial sector in 
the Philippines is currently bank-dominated and heavily unbalanced in its structural composition.  Development of a 
sound nonbank financial sector is key to providing effective alternate means of corporate finance as well as 
strengthening overall financial sector integrity.

Analysis: 
Job creation has not kept pace with the growth of the labor force and unemployment continues to be high and rising.  
Higher levels of investment are necessary if the economy is to attain a higher growth path and unemployment is to be 
reduced.   
 
The financial sector clearly has a central part to play in this effort through its role in channeling savings to productive 
investment to finance growth. Currently, however, the financial sector in the Philippines is bank-dominated and 
lending by the banking system to the corporate sector has been highly constrained by nonperforming loans (NPLs) 
that have steadily accumulated since the crisis (latest estimates point to NPLs at above 15% of commercial banks’ 
total assets). The high level of NPLs within the banking system and overreliance of the corporate sector on bank 
lending are symptomatic of poor lending, weak governance in the financial sector, and lack of alternative sources of 
financing to the banking system. The need for reforms to address these distortions and support the development of a 
sound nonbank financial sector is fundamental if the financial sector is to act as a facilitator of rather than a constraint 
to long-term economic growth. 
 
Investment has also been significantly hindered by weak investor sentiment due in part to chronic and widespread 
graft and corruption. The Government's efforts establishing an effective anti-money laundering regime, represent an 
important step forward in addressing this problem, as an effective regime has the potential to serve as a key tool in 
tackling graft and corruption.
